choices.text: Risk of seizure is maximal from day 3 to day 5.
The chances of having a delirium is highest after 5 days
Having withdrawal symptoms 5 days after abstinence is unusual
Alcohol withdrawal symptoms usually starts within 48 hours

questions.text: A 34-year-old patient who has been dependent on alcohol meets with a road traffic accident and is admitted at an orthopaedic ward for fractured wrist. Which of the following is correct with respect to his clinical state?
questions.solution:
The classic sign of alcohol withdrawal is tremulousness, although the spectrum of symptoms can expand to include psychotic and perceptual symptoms (e.g., delusions and hallucinations), seizures, and the symptoms of delirium tremens (DTs ), called alcohol delirium in DSM-5. Tremulousness (commonly called the 'shakes' or the 'jitters') develops 6 to 8 hours after the cessation of drinking, the psychotic and perceptual symptoms begin in 8 to 12 hours, seizures in 12 to 24 hours, and DTs anytime during the first 72 hours, although physicians should watch for the development of DTs for the first week of withdrawal. The syndrome of withdrawal sometimes skips the usual progression and, for example, goes directly to DTs.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 20, substance use and addictive disorders, page 630

choices.text: Total duration being less than 30 secs

questions.text: Which of the following points towards pseudo seizures rather than epileptic seizures?
questions.solution: Reference: PG notes in psychiatry, Cijo Alex, 2nd edition, chapter 42, epilepsy, page 413

questions.text: What is the most suitable drug for a depressed palliative care patient suffering with nausea and vomiting following chemotherapy?
questions.solution:
Depression is common but often not recognized at the end of life.

Treating these population can be beneficial even if the prognosis is short. Mirtazapine and citalopram are most strongly suggested in these population.

5HT3 antagonism of mirtazapine also helps in drug induced nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, stomach cramps and other gastrointestinal side effects.

Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Chapter 10, page 829

Stephen M. Stahl - Prescriber's Guide, 6th edition, Mirtazapine, Page 483

choices.text: Raised white cell count on lumbar puncture
MRI scan shows atrophy of head of the caudate nucleus
EEG shows spike and wave activity
HMPAO-SPECT scan shows patchy hypo perfusion throughout the brain

questions.text: Which of the following investigatory findings is most supportive of a diagnosis of Huntington's disease?
questions.solution:
• Huntington's Disease is an autosomal dominant disease with CAG trinucleotide repeats seen on Huntington's (HTT) gene located on chromosome 4. The normal repeat length in the HTT gene is 36 or less. An expansion of 40 or more codons causes Huntington's disease, with a correlation between size of expansion and virulence of the disease. Large expansions tend to result in earlier onset of disease. The presenting symptoms are neurological and psychiatric. Neurological presentations are usually with choreiform movements, or less often with unsteadiness of gait, a tendency to fall or general clumsiness. Psychiatric presentations could be dementia, emotional disturbance and paranoia.
  • Electroencephalography characteristically shows poorly developed or complete loss of alpha rhythms. There may be generalised low-voltage fast activity or random slow activity, but this too may disappear as the disease progress.
  • Computed tomography and MRI show dilated ventricles, often particularly affecting the frontal regions. Atrophy of the heads of the caudate nuclei may be clearly apparent, with loss of the normal convex bulging into the lateral walls of the frontal horns.
  • CTG trinucleotide repeats are seen in myotonic dystrophy.

Reference: Lishman's organic Psychiatry, A textbook of neuropsychiatry, Fourth edition, chapter 9, Alzheimer's Disease and Other Dementias (Including Pseudo dementias), pg 576-584

questions.text: Match the following scenarios with the defence mechanisms being used.
questions.solution:
Passive aggressive behaviour- Aggression toward an object expressed indirectly and ineffectively through passivity, masochism, and turning against the self.

Displacement Involves a purposeful, unconscious shifting of impulses or affective investment from one object to another in the interest of solving a conflict. Although the object is changed, the instinctual nature of the impulse and its aim remain unchanged.

Intellectualization The control of affects and impulses by way of thinking about them instead of experiencing them. It is a systematic excess of thinking, deprived of its affect, to defend against anxiety caused by unacceptable impulses.

Reaction formation The management of unacceptable impulses by permitting expression of the impulse in antithetical form. This is equivalently an expression of the impulse in the negative. Where instinctual conflict is persistent, reaction formation can become a character trait on a permanent basis, usually as an aspect of obsessional character.

Sublimation The gratification of an impulse whose goal is retained but whose aim or object is changed from a socially objectionable one to a socially valued one. Sublimation of aggressive impulses takes place through pleasurable games and sports.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 4, theories of personality and psycho pathology, page 160-162

questions.text: OCD is associated with an abnormality in which of the following parts of the brain?
questions.solution:
Basal ganglia dysfunction is implicated in OCD. The components of basal ganglia are the caudate nucleus, the putamen and globus pallidus. Putamen and globus pallidus together form the lenticular/lentiform nuclei. Neuroimaging studies with PET scan suggest the involvement of both caudate and lentiform nuclei dysfunction in patients with OCD.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 10.1, obsessive compulsive disorder, page 419

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is referred for an evaluation of school problems. Her teachers and parents describe her as argumentative, hostile, disrespectful, and difficult. The girl often refuses to listen, will not obey instructions, does not do her work, has temper tantrums, and insists on having her ow n way. She has been this way since preschool. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Oppositional defiant disorder is characterized by a pattern of angry/irritable mood, argumentative/defiant behavior or vindictiveness lasting atleast 6 months usually towards authority figures which results in distress in the individuals in patient's immediate social context.
  • Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder is characterized by a pattern of diminished sustained attention and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity which must be present by age 12 as per DSM V.
  • Antisocial personality disorder is inability to conform to the social norms that ordinarily govern many aspects of a person's adolescent and adult behavior. Characterized by continuous criminal act and antisocial acts occurring since age 15. however, the patient must be of 18 years of age to make a diagnoses of antisocial personality disorder as per DSM V. the childhood counterpart of the same is known as conduct disorder.
  • Intermittent explosive disorder manifests as discrete episodes of losing control of aggressive impulses resulting in serious assault or destruction of property. The aggressiveness is grossly out of proportion to the stressor that may have elicited the episode.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, chapter 2, neurodevelopmental disorders and other childhood disorders

questions.text: A 67-year-old female patient was brought to psychiatric opd with low mood, sadness, poor appetite and sleep, feeling of worthlessness, hallucinations of her husband, passive thoughts of dying to meet her husband following the death of her husband 2 months ago?
questions.solution:
Normal bereavement begins immediately after or within a few months of the loss of a loved one. Typical signs and symptoms include feelings of sadness, preoccupation with thoughts about the deceased, tearfulness, irritability, insomnia, and difficulties concentrating and carrying out daily activities. Some grieving individuals present with symptoms characteristic of a major depressive episode. However, the presence of specific symptoms that are not characteristic of a “normal” grief reaction may help differentiate bereavement from depression. These include

(1) guilt about things other than actions taken or not taken by the survivor at the time of the death,

(2) thoughts of death other than the survivor feeling that he or she would be better off dead or should have died with the deceased person,

(3) morbid preoccupation with worthlessness,

(4) marked psychomotor retardation,

(5) prolonged and marked functional impairment, and

(6) hallucinatory experiences other than thinking that he or she hears the voice of or transiently sees the image of the deceased person.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, chapter 20, Bereavement

questions.text: Which of the following differentiates Lewy body dementia from dementia of the Alzheimer's type?
questions.solution:
• Lewy body disease is a dementia clinically similar to Alzheimer's disease and often characterized by hallucinations, parkinsonian features, and extrapyramidal signs Lewy inclusion bodies are found in the cerebral cortex. These patients often have Capgras syndrome (reduplicative paramnesia) as part of the clinical picture.
  • Lewy bodies are weakly eosinophilic, spherical, cytoplasmic inclusions containing alpha synuclein.
  • Cortical Lewy bodies are less conspicuous, less eosinophilic and lack clear halo compared to those in the substantia nigra.
  • Choreiform movements are seen in dementia with huntington's disease

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, chapter 3.2 Dementia

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient who is being evaluated for depression reveals that she worries excessively about her Weight. She states that she is unable to diet and consumes large quantities of food about once a month. However, she then feels guilty and uses laxatives to lose the excess calories. She appears to have normal weight for her height. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Bulimia nervosa is characterized by episodes of binge eating combined with inappropriate ways of stopping weight gain. Physical discomfort-for example, abdominal pain or nausea terminates the binge eating, which is often followed by feelings of guilt, depression, or self-disgust. Unlike patients with anorexia nervosa, those with bulimia nervosa typically maintain a normal body weight.
  • While in anorexia nervosa, patients have a relentless drive for thinness, behaviours aimed at reducing weight such as diet, starvation or purging. There are two subtypes of anorexia: restricting type, binge eating/purging. Even though binge eating/purging appears similar to bulimia nervosa the main differentiating feature is normal BMI in bulimia while usually lower BMI in anorexia patients.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 10.2, Body dysmorphic disorder ,page 427

  • Body dysmorphic disorder is characterized by preoccupation with one or more perceived defects in appearance that are not observed by others or are slight to others.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 15 feeding and eating disorder

  • Patients with factitious disorder simulate, induce, or aggravate illness to receive medical attention, regardless of whether or not they are ill. Thus, they may inflict painful, deforming, or even life-threatening injury on themselves, their children, or other dependents. The primary motivation is not avoidance of duties, financial gain, or anything concrete. The motivation is simply to receive medical care and to partake in the medical system.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 13.6 Factitious disorder, page 489

questions.text: The consultation-liaison psychiatrist is called to the emergency department to evaluate a 17-year-old patient who is highly agitated and floridly psychotic with findings of ataxia, nystagmus,' dysarthria, and elevated blood pressure. Intoxication with which of the following substances best explains this presentation?
questions.solution:
• Phencyclidine or PCP is hallucinogen which produces effects such as speedy feelings, euphoria, bodily warmth or hyperthermia, tingling, depersonalization, and sometimes auditory and visual hallucinations. Some individuals may also experienc3 distortion of space and time perception and delusions. Anxiety is often the most prominent presenting symptoms along with nystagmus, hypertension and ataxia.
  • Cannabis intoxication commonly heightens users' sensitivity to external stimuli, makes colors seem brighter and richer, subjective slowing of time, euphoria, increased appetite and sometime depersonalization and derealization. Physical effects include conjunctival injection(red eyes) mild tachycardia and orthostatic hypotension at high doses.
  • Heroin intoxication causes maladaptive behavior changes and specific physical symptoms of opioid use such as altered mood, euphoria, drowsiness, slurred speech, miosis, constipation ,hypotension, bradycardia and respiratory depression in overdose.
  • Psilocybin is a naturally occurring psychedelic prodrug produced by various species of fungi. psilocybin is itself inactive biologically however it is quickly converted to psilocin which has effects similar to LSD or mescaline such as euphoria, hallucinations, changes in perception ,distorted sense of time and perceived spiritual experience. Psilocybin mushrooms or magic mushrooms have long been consumed in various spiritual and religious practices.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 20, substance use and addictive disorders

questions.text: Patients who suffer from depression after a myocardial infarction should be treated with which of the following antidepressants?
questions.solution:
• Of the above mentioned medications SSRIs are generally recommended is patients with cardiac disease however caution should be paid to SSRIs anti platelet activity and cytochrome medicated interactions with co administered cardiac drugs. Of the SSRIs, sertraline is considered the most cardio safe and is the drug of choice in post MI patients.
  • TCAs are contraindicated in patients with recent MI.

Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, chapter 3, page 383-386

questions.text: A 29-year-old unmarried woman is admitted to an acute inpatient unit after police spotted her wandering along a busy highway gesturing and muttering to herself. On admission, she was disheveled and bizarrely clothed. Her speech was tangential, and she reported auditory hallucinations commenting on her behavior and telling her that 'criminal elements' were watching her. She had recently been residing with her parents and gave permission for staff to contact them. Her parents report that her first hospitalization was at age 25, just after she began working on her thesis for a Ph.D. in mathematics. She responded rapidly to treatment with risperidone 3 mg daily, and several months later, with the support of her adviser, she was able to resume work on her thesis. Over the past 6 months, after she decided to stop her medication, her symptoms have returned. In responding to the parents' questions about her prognosis, which of the following factors would be the best predictor of a good prognosis for this patient?
questions.solution: Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 7: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders, page 318

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cluster c personality disorder?
questions.solution:
All of the above mentioned personality disorders except antisocial personality disorder are part of cluster c personality disorder.

Antisocial personality disorder belong to cluster B personality disorders. Other cluster B personality disorders are Histrionic, Narcissistic and borderline personality disorders.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 22, personality disorders, page 742

questions.text: The image depicts which disorder?
questions.solution:
Catatonia is a clinical syndrome characterized by striking behavioural abnormalities that may include motoric immobility or excitement, stupor(i .e., no psychomotor activity; not actively relating to environment), profound negativism (i .e., opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli), or echolalia (mimicry of speech) or echopraxia (mimicry of movement). A diagnosis of catatonic disorder due to a general medical condition can be made if there is evidence that the condition is due to the physiological effects of a general medical condition. The diagnosis is not made if the catatonia is better explained by a primary mental disorder, such as schizophrenia or psychotic depression, or if catatonic symptoms occur exclusively within the course of delirium.

Posturing (i .e., spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity), one of the symptoms of catatonia is seen in the image above.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 7, Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders, page 345

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has been recently diagnosed with Major depressive disorder following a major financial loss. Patient has a family history of major depressive disorder in mother and hypertension and diabetes in father. Patient has a history of GERD and Hypertension for which he has been taking antihypertensives and antacids. On examination patient has dysphoric mood and psychomotor retardation. BP- 150/90 mm HG, pulse 82/min, rest all physical examination findings are normal. Which of the following medications should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Higher-dose venlafaxine (selective serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) therapy is associated with an increased risk of sustained elevations of blood pressure (BP). In view of the family history of hypertension and uncontrolled hypertension in patient himself, venlafaxine should better be avoided in this case.

The other most frequently observed side effect of venlafaxine is nausea.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 29,psychopharmacological treatment, page 1011

questions.text: A 35-year-old female who was violently assaulted 3 years ago suffers from hypervigilance, recurrent nightmares, flashbacks, difficulty concentrating and emotional numbness. Which of the following is not an effective treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
• Post-traumatic stress disorder is marked by increased stress and anxiety following a traumatic experience. The traumatic experience or stressor may include being a witness to or being involved in a violent accident or crime, military combat, or assault, being kidnapped, being involved in a natural disaster, being diagnosed with a life-threatening illness, or experiencing systematic physical or sexual abuse etc. The person reacts to the experience with fear and helplessness, persistently relives the event, and tries to avoid being reminded of it. The event may be relived in dreams and waking thoughts (flashbacks).
  • Pharmacological management includes use of either SSRIs, or tricyclics like imipramine, amitriptyline, benzodiazepines, buspirone.
  • Non pharmacological managements include behavior therapy, cognitive therapy, hypnosis, abreaction, EMDR.
  • eye movement desensitization and reprocessing (EMDR), is a form of therapy in which the patient focuses on the lateral movement of the clinician's finger while maintaining a mental image of the trauma experience. The general belief is that symptoms can be relieved as patients work through the traumatic event while in a state of deep relaxation.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 11,trauma and stress related disorders, page 445

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the emergency department complaining of migraine headache. A review of her medical file reveals one brief admission for a transient psychotic episode and depression within the past 3 years. She is noted to be dressed in odd clothing. She insists that she is clairvoyant and telepathic. Her speech is noted to be metaphorical, overelaborate, and stereotyped. She says she has no close friends or confidants other than her mother, and that this has been the case since she was a teenager. She is not particularly bothered about her lack of companionship. Her presentation is most consistent with which of the following personality disorders?
questions.solution:
• Persons with schizotypal personality disorder are strikingly odd or strange, even to laypersons. Magical thinking, peculiar notions, ideas of reference, illusions, and derealization are part of a schizotypal person's everyday world. These patients may be superstitious or claim powers of clairvoyance and may believe that they have other special powers of thought and insight. Their inner world may be filled with vivid imaginary relationships and child-like fears and fantasies. They may admit to perceptual illusions or macropsia and confess that other persons seem wooden and all the same.
  • Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by a lifelong pattern of social withdrawal. Persons with schizoid personality disorder are often seen by others as eccentric, isolated, or lonely. Their discomfort with human interaction; their introversion; and their bland, constricted affect are noteworthy.
  • Persons with avoidant personality disorder show extreme sensitivity to rejection and may lead socially withdrawn lives. Although shy, they are not asocial and show a great desire for companionship, but they need unusually strong guarantees of uncritical acceptance. Such persons are commonly described as having an inferiority complex.
  • Persons with histrionic personality disorder are excitable and emotional and behave in a colorful, dramatic, extroverted fashion. Accompanying their flamboyant aspects, however, is often an inability to maintain deep, long-lasting attachments.
  • The hallmarks of paranoid personality disorder are excessive suspiciousness and distrust of others expressed as a pervasive tendency to interpret actions of others as deliberately demeaning, malevolent, threatening, exploiting, or deceiving.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 22, Personality Disorders

questions.text: A 23-year-old patient with chronic schizophrenia complains of a milky discharge from her nipples. Medication-induced antagonism of which of the following receptors is responsible?
questions.solution:
This patient developed drug induced hyperprolactinemia.

Antipsychotic medications block dopamine receptors in major dopamine pathways of brain i.e, mesolimbic, mesocortical, nigrostriatal, tuberoinfundibular and thalamic.

Blockade of dopamine receptors in the mesolimbic pathway is responsible for improvement in positive symptoms. However, blockade in nigrostriatal pathway causes extrapyramidal side effects while blockade in tuberoinfundibular pathway causes elevation in prolactin

( dopamine inhibits prolactin)

Reference: stahl's essential psychopharmacology, fifth edition, chapter 4, psychosis, schizophrenia and neurotransmitter networks, page 85

questions.text: A husband-and-wife present for treatment because the wife if concerned. Her husband recently told her that he believes he was born a woman. He states that he has always felt this way but can't fight it anymore. He has started wearing dresses around the house after he arrives home from work at the end of the day. He says that he loves his wife and kids but that he needs to be happy as well. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Gender dysphoria or gender identity disorder as it was previously knows, refers to a marked incongruence between one's biological or assigned sex and one's experienced or expressed gender. Gender identity refers to one's belonging to either gender male or female. These individuals have marked distress with their biological sex and have a strong desire to have the body of the other sex or to be socially recognized as the other sex.
  • Transvestism, formerly called transvestic fetishism, is described as fantasies and sexual urges to dress in opposite gender clothing as a means of arousal and as an adjunct to masturbation or coitus. However there is no incongruence between one's assigned and experienced gender.
  • Voyeurism, also known as scopophilia, is the recurrent preoccupation with fantasies and acts that involve observing unsuspecting persons who are naked or engaged in grooming or sexual activity. Masturbation to orgasm usually accompanies or follows the event.
  • Exhibitionism is the recurrent urge to expose the genitals to a stranger or to an unsuspecting person. Sexual excitement occurs in anticipation of the exposure, and orgasm is brought about by masturbation during or after the event

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 17, human sexuality and sexual dysfunctions

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman develops anorgasmia while taking paroxetine. Switching to which of the following medications is most likely to resolve this problem?
questions.solution:
• Antidepressants can cause sedation, hormonal changes, disturbances in cholinergic/adrenergic balance, peripheral alpha adrenergic agonism, inhibition of nitric oxide, all of which can result in sexual dysfunction.
  • Sexual dysfunction with antidepressants are usually dose dependent and fully reversible once the antidepressant is stopped.
  • Sexual dysfunction has been reported as a side effect of many antidepressants however the rates may vary and individual susceptibility may also vary.
  • SSRIs have high rates of all sexual dysfunctions such as loss of libido, anorgasmia and delayed ejaculation.
  • Bupropion and mirtazapine have the lowest potency to cause sexual dysfunction.

Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, chapter 3, depression and anxiety disorder, page 405

choices.text: Brief psychotic disorder without marked stressor

questions.text: A previously well 24-year-old woman presented with a 4-week history of progressively worsening expansive irritable mood, pressured speech, racing thoughts, grandiosity, and distractibility. More recently she heard the voice of God proclaiming her to be a special messenger. She does not have any past of family history of any psychiatric disorders. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
As per DSM 5, a distinct period of abnormally and persistently elevated, expansive or irritable mood and abnormally and persistently elevated goal directed activity lasting at least a week along with atleast 3 of the following symptoms( four if mood is irritable) is characterized as a manic episode.

  • Grandiosity
  • Reduced need for sleep
  • Talkativeness
  • Flight of ideas
  • Distractibility
  • Increased goal directed activities
  • Excessive involvement in high risk activities

Bipolar I disorder is defined as having a clinical course of one or more manic episodes and, sometimes, major depressive episodes.

Presence of auditory hallucinations make bipolar disorder with psychotic features a likely diagnosis in this case.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 8, major depression and bipolar disorder, page 359

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents with symptoms of depression. She is always thinking that the worst will occur in her relationships and employment, and she feels powerless to alter or control these events. She is seeking treatment with a therapist who provides cognitive behavior therapy. What is the most likely focus of the therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
• According to cognitive theory, depression results from specific cognitive distortions known as depressogenic schemata. These distortions are maladaptive patterns of thinking that perceive both internal and external data in ways that are altered by early experiences. Such distortions include selective attention to the negative aspects of circumstances and unrealistically morbid inferences about consequences.
  • Therapy consists of modifying these distortions.
  • The goal of cognitive therapy is to alleviate depressive episodes and prevent their recurrence by helping patients identify and test negative cognitions; develop alternative, flexible, and positive ways of thinking; and rehearse new cognitive and behavioral responses.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 28, psychotherapies, page 873

questions.text: Methylphenidate has its greatest action on which of the following neurotransmitter systems?
questions.solution:
Mechanism of action of methylphenidate - dopamine norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor and releaser

Indication- attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

Reference: Stahl's essential psychopharmacology, prescriber's guide, 6th edition, Methylphenidate, page 449

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient with a history of schizophrenia since last 2 years presents to emergency room with eyeballs turned upwards. Patient was given Inj Haloperidol the previous night for acute behavioural problems. Which of the following medication is best suitable to this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient developed oculogyric crisis following antipsychotic administration.

Drug induced dystonia is the first EPS to develop, more common in young male,antipsychotic naive, with high potency antipsychotic administration

May occur within hours of starting antipsychotics

Clinical features: muscle spasm in any part of the body

Oculogyric crisis: eyes turning upwards

Torticollis: Head and neck twisted to one side

Laryngeal spasm- can lead to death

Treatment: anticholinergics given oral, IV or IM, like promethazine in the above case

Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, chapter 1, schizophrenia and related psychosis, page 110-111

questions.text: Which of the following psychosocial treatments is most likely to be effective in the treatment of obsessive compulsive disorder?
questions.solution:
Well-controlled studies have found that pharmacotherapy, behavior therapy, or a combination of both is effective in significantly reducing the symptoms of patients with OCD. Although few head-to-head comparisons have been made, behavior therapy is as effective as pharmacotherapies in OCD, and some data indicate that the beneficial effects are longer lasting with behavior therapy. Many clinicians, therefore, consider behavior therapy the treatment of choice for OCD. The principal behavioral approaches in OCD are exposure and response prevention. Desensitization, flooding, implosion therapy, and aversive conditioning have also been used in patients with OCD.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 10, obsessive compulsive disorder, page 425

questions.text: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) appears to be most strongly associated with prenatal exposure to:
questions.solution:
• ADHD is a complex disorder of multifactorial etiology, thought to have multiple genetic and environmental variables of small effect acting together to produce vulnerability to ADHD. Although the etiology of ADHD yet has to be determined, there is a growing consensus that the condition involves functional and anatomical dysfunction in the brain's cortico-basal ganglia thalamo-cortical circuitry
  • In utero risk factors include prenatal exposure to alcohol, nicotine, recreational drugs, glucocorticoids, the toxins hexachlorobenzene and polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs), poor maternal diet and maternal stress during pregnancy.
  • Perinatal risk factors include prematurity, low birth weight, and obstetric complications.
  • ADHD has also been associated with childhood illnesses such as meningitis, encephalitis, cardiac disease, thyroid disease, epilepsy, head trauma, and autoimmune and metabolic disorders.
  • Prenatal exposure to lithium is linked to ebstein anoaly while valproic acid is linked to cognitive impairment and neural tube defects and SSRIs to persistent pulmonary hypertension.

Reference: Kaplan And Sadock's comprehensive textbook of psychiatry, 10th edition, volume 2, chapter 45, Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is diagnosed with bipolar I disorder. He has a previous history of several suicide attempts. Of the following medications, which would be the most likely to decrease his risk for suicide if administered on a long-term basis?
questions.solution:
Lithium reduces the risk of both attempted and completed suicide in patients with bipolar disorder. Lithium treated patients are less likely to complete suicide than patients treated with other mood stabilizing drugs.

Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, chapter 2, bipolar disorders, page 249

questions.text: A 25-year-old man collects women's bras and underpants from public laundries and uses the objects to get sexually aroused. This description is most consistent with which of the following diagnoses?
questions.solution:
• In fetishism the sexual focus is on objects (e.g., shoes, gloves, pantyhose, and stockings) that are intimately associated with the human body, or on non genital body parts. Sexual activity may be directed toward the fetish itself (e.g., masturbation with or into a shoe), or the fetish may be incorporated into sexual intercourse (e.g., the demand that high-heeled shoes be worn).
  • While kleptomania is recurrent urges to steal objects not needed for personal use or monetary value, they are not involved with sexual pleasure.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 17, human sexuality and sexual dysfunctions, page 595

questions.text: Trichotillomania is a difficult symptom to treat with either psychotherapy or medication. Emerging evidence indicates that medication plus which of the following types of psychotherapy is effective?
questions.solution:
Habit reversal therapy (HRT) is a set of cognitive behavioral techniques that has been shown efficacious in the treatment of childhood and adult Trichotillomania. Components of HRT include awareness training, competing response training, and social support. Awareness training includes elements such as self-monitoring and collecting pulled hair. In competing response training, the patient substitutes hair-pulling with an incompatible action (e.g., first-clenching). Social support involves the use of another individual to reinforce the competing response, and may be particularly useful in pediatric TTM. In addition, stimulus control (SC) is used to change the patient's environment so that hair-pulling is more effortful and/or less reinforcing.

Reference: Kaplan And Sadock's comprehensive textbook of psychiatry, 10th edition, volume 1, chapter 15, obsessive compulsive and related disorders

questions.text: Kidney stones are most likely to be a side effect of which of the following?
questions.solution:
The most common adverse effects of topiramate include paraesthesias, weight loss, somnolence, anorexia, dizziness, and memory problems. Sometimes disturbances in the sense of taste occur. In many cases, the adverse effects are mild to moderate and can be attenuated by decreasing the dose. The drug affects acid-base balance (low serum bicarbonate), which can be associated with cardiac arrhythmias, and the formation of renal calculi in about 1. 5% of cases. Patients taking the drug should be encouraged to drink plenty of fluids.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 29.6, psychopharmacological treatment, page 938-939

questions.text: Genetic studies of obsessive-compulsive disorder have revealed linkages to which of the following disorders?
questions.solution:
studies have suggested a possible link between a subset of OCD cases and certain types of motor tic syndromes (i.e., Tourette's disorder and chronic motor tics). A higher rate of OCD, Tourette 's disorder, and chronic motor tics are found in relatives of patients with Tourette 's disorder than in relatives of controls, whether or not they had OCD. Most family studies of probands with OCD have found increased rates of Tourette 's disorder and chronic motor tics only among the relatives of probands with OCD who also have some form of tic disorder. Evidence also suggests co transmission of Tourette 's disorder, OCD, and chronic motor tics within families.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 10, obsessive compulsive and related disorders, page 420

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely symptom in cocaine intoxication?
questions.solution:
Cocaine intoxication can produce hypertension, tachycardia, seizures, paranoid delusions, and delirium. Depersonalization is more commonly associated with hallucinogen intoxication.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 20, substance use disorders, page 672

questions.text: Patients with bulimia nervosa who engage in binge/purge behaviors are at risk for which of the following medical disorders?
questions.solution:
In patients with bulimia nervosa, cardiomyopathy as a result starvation or chronic use of emetics such as ipecac or chronic alcohol abuse which is often seen with eating disorders. certain nutritional deficiency such as thiamine or magnesium may also result in cardiomyopathy. Severe cardiomyopathy can lead to heart failure or be a risk factor for cardiac arrhythmia. Patients who binge and vomit may have parotid gland enlargement associated with elevated serum amylase levels. They are susceptible to hypokalemic alkalosis. Unlike patients with anorexia nervosa, those with bulimia do not have a high risk of osteopenia.

Reference: Kaplan And Sadock's comprehensive textbook of psychiatry, 10th edition, volume 1, chapter 22, feeding and eating disorders

questions.text: Cocaine-induced euphoria is most highly associated with which of the following neurotransmitters?
questions.solution:
Cocaine is known to inhibit dopamine reuptake and increase extracellular dopamine concentration. These effects, which occur in the nucleus accumbens, are considered to be related to cocaine-induced euphoria. Cocaine also blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin, although the behavioral effects are mediated primarily by the dopaminergic system. The inhibitory neurotransmitter gamma-aminobutyric acid also interacts with dopamine neurons in the nucleus accumbens and the ventral tegmental area. The binding of cocaine to the dopamine transporter correlates best with its behavioral potency.

Reference- Stahl's essential psychopharmacology, fourth edition, Chapter 14, impulsivity, compulsivity and addiction, page 543-544

choices.text: Acuity of onset and level of consciousness

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiates delirium from dementia of the Alzheimer's type?
questions.solution:
Delirium is often confused with dementia or functional psychiatric disorders in elderly patients. Clinical features help in differentiating between delirium and dementia. Patients with delirium have an acute onset and exhibit fluctuation in the level of consciousness, cognition, and clinical symptoms, whereas patients with Alzheimer's dementia tend to have an insidious onset and an alert and stable level of consciousness, and cognitive and symptom fluctuation are infrequent. Orientation and memory are impaired in both disorders. Visual hallucinations are frequent in delirium and occur only occasionally in Alzheimer's dementia. EEG shows marked slowing in patients with delirium and either normal or mild slowing in patients with Alzheimer's dementia.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 21, neurocognitive disorders, page 694-718

questions.text: A consultation is requested for a 16-year-old male who has been in detention for the past 2 months on charges of possession of cocaine. The detention center staff describe the youth as hyperactive, inattentive, impulsive, and easily distracted. A review of his educational history indicates that the youth has been in special education classes since the first grade because of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and a mixed expressive receptive language disorder. On examination, there is no evidence of a mood or anxiety disorder or current substance abuse. Which of the following medications would be most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Atomoxetine is a nonstimulant medication used for the treatment of ADHD. The drug is a potent inhibitor of presynaptic norepinephrine transporters with minimal affinity for other receptors or transporters. The most common side effects associated with it, which are generally mild, include sedation, decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, and dizziness. Because atomoxetine is not known to be abusable, it is an excellent alternative for use with youths who have a history of illicit substance use or abuse and ADHD. Amphetamine has a potential for abuse and would not be a good choice for this patient. The other three agents listed are considered second-line agents for ADHD and should be tried only after a failed trial of a first-line agent.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, chapter 31.6, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, page 1175-1178

questions.text: Which of the following medications can cause fatal intestinal obstruction?
questions.solution:
Rapidly fatal intestinal obstruction has been reported with clozapine, sometimes even without prior warning signs.Due to its muscarinic receptor blacking property. Some case reports also implicate risperidone and olanzapine in intestinal obstructions.

Reference: Stahl's essential psychopharmacology, prescriber's guide, 6th edition, clozapine, page 179

questions.text: Which of the following behavioural treatment is useful in trichotillomania?
questions.solution:
• Habit reversal therapy (HRT) is a set of cognitive behavioral techniques that has been shown efficacious in the treatment of childhood and adult Trichotillomania. Components of HRT include awareness training, competing response training, and social support. Awareness training includes elements such as self-monitoring and collecting pulled hair. In competing response training, the patient substitutes hair-pulling with an incompatible action (e.g., first-clenching). Social support involves the use of another individual to reinforce the competing response, and may be particularly useful in pediatric TTM. In addition, stimulus control (SC) is used to change the patient's environment so that hair-pulling is more effortful and/or less reinforcing.
  • Exposure and response prevention is a useful technique in obsessive compulsive disorder
  • Biofeedback provides stimulus cues for physiological markers of relaxation and can increase self-awareness. A machine is used to measure muscle tension. Patients require careful and adequate training; simply giving them an instruction tape is not especially helpful.

Reference: Kaplan And Sadock's comprehensive textbook of psychiatry, 10th edition, volume 1, chapter 15, obsessive compulsive and related disorders

questions.text: A 25 year old man originally from Malaysia presents with an episode of sudden and intense anxiety that his penis will recede into his body and cause death. The most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Koro is a culture bound syndrome which is characterized by an overpowering belief that sex organs are retracting and will disappear. Usually seen in individuals from south east asia.
  • Dhat Refers to severe anxiety and hypochondriacal concerns associated with the seminal discharge accompanied by feeling weak and exhausted. Seen in India and southeast Asia
  • Latah refers to Hypersensitivity to sudden fright, often with echopraxia, echolalia, command obedience, and dissociative or trancelike behaviour seen in middle-aged women
  • Frigophobia refers to a morbid fear of feeling cold / wind due to presumed yin-yang imbalance. Yin-yang refers to Oriental psychological notion of two opposing forces; yin is dark, female and negative force. Yang is bright, male and positive force. Excessive yin in males leads to pa-leng or pa-feng Affected men typically bundle themselves in warm clothing, avoid wind or drafts, and eat foods that are symbolically and calorically hot ' while avoiding foods that are cold < /li>
< p > Reference: Kaplan and Sadock & rsquo;s comprehensive textbook of psychiatry, 10 < sup > th < /sup> edition, volume 2, chapter 29.1, cultural concepts of distress

questions.text: Which of the following is an established risk factor for experiencing depression during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Women with a previous history of a mood disorder severe enough to require treatment including counselling or medication are at greater risk of developing depression during pregnancy than women with no prior history of a mood disorder.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 27, psychiatry and reproductive medicine, page 839

questions.text: A 32 year old patient, since delivering a baby boy, has been very tearful, low and avoiding food. She spends most nights awake in a fearful state and for the last 2 weeks has found it difficult to breastfeed her baby and believes that her breasts are involuting. She does not recognize her husband and feels that he has sexually assaulted her. Patient refuses to breastfeed her baby. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Postpartum psychosis is an example of a psychotic disorder that occurs in women who have recently delivered a baby. The syndrome is often characterized by the mother's depression, delusions, and thoughts of harming either herself or her infant. Such ideation of suicide or infanticide must be carefully monitored; although rare, some mothers have acted on these ideas. Most available data suggest a close relation between postpartum psychosis and mood disorders, particularly bipolar disorder and major depressive disorder. It is Given the immediacy of onset and psychopathology suggestive of delusions, this lady is most likely having postpartum psychosis.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 27, psychiatry and reproductive medicine, page 840

questions.text: A 35 year old man in your inpatient unit keeps his ears blocked with cotton and tape. He is disturbed by two persons discussing between themselves about every movement that he makes. They also discuss his emotions and plans.
questions.solution:
• Third person hallucinations are auditory hallucinations in which patients hear voices talking about themselves, referring to them in the third person, for example 'he is an evil person'. This type of auditory hallucination is particularly associated with schizophrenia, but can occur in affective disorders.
  • 1stperson hallucination is hearing one's own thoughts spoken aloud.
  • 2ndperson hallucination is hearing voices talking directly to patient.
  • Thought broadcast- patient may feel that their thoughts are no longer private and are accessible to everyone

Reference- Fish's clinical psychopathology, 3rd edition, chapter 2, disorders of perception, page 21- 23

questions.text: A 37 year old female patient is brought to the emergency room with complaint of inner restlessness and a strong desire to move for the last 2 days. Family members have also observed her stamping her foot frequently when seated. Patient was given Inj Olanzapine 3 days ago for her auditory hallucinations. Patient is suffering from which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Akathisia is subjective feelings of restlessness, objective signs of restlessness, or both. Examples include a sense of anxiety, inability to relax, jitteriness, pacing, rocking motions while sitting, and rapid alternation of sitting and standing.
  • Acute akathisia may develop within weeks to hours of starting antipsychotic medication or increasing the dose
  • More common in middle aged females
  • Treatment- reduce the dose of antipsychotics, change to antipsychotics with low propensity to cause akathisia, low dose propranolol, clonazepam, 5HT2 antagonists such as cyproheptadine, mirtazapine, trazodone

Reference: The Maudsley® Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, chapter 1, schizophrenia and related psychosis, page 110

questions.text: A woman believes that the tennis player Roger Federer is in love with her. She has never seen him in person but believes that he is delivering romantic e-mails to her inbox in various disguised names. She is exhibiting
questions.solution:
In De clerambault's delusion or delusion of erotomania, the patient has the delusional conviction that another person, usually of higher status, is in love with him or her. Such patients also tend to be solitary, withdrawn, dependent, and sexually inhibited as well as to have poor levels of social or occupational functioning.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 7: Schizophrenia Spectrum and Other Psychotic Disorders, page 334

questions.text: A patient can hear voices whenever the noise of water running through a tap is heard. This is called
questions.solution:
In functional hallucination, an auditory stimulus causes a hallucination but the stimulus is experienced as well as the hallucination.In other words,the hallucination requires the presence of another real sensation.For example, a patient with schizophrenia first heard the voice of God as her clock ticked; later she heard voices coming from the running tap and voices coming from the chirruping of the birds

Reference- Fish's clinical psychopathology,3rd edition, chapter 2, Disorders of perception, page 26-28

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with schizophrenia resists moving his limbs during a neurological examination. Despite repeated reassurances from the examining doctor, he resists yielding his limbs for passive manipulations. He is exhibiting
questions.solution:
Negativism is an apparently motiveless resistance to all interference. It is found in catatonia, severe learning disability and dementia. Negativism may be passive when all interference is resisted and orders are not carried out, or it may manifest as active when the patient does the exact opposite of what they are asked to do, in a reflex manner

Reference- Diagnostic and statistical manual of mental disorders, 5th edition, Catatonia, page 119

questions.text: Ailurophobia is
questions.solution:
Fear of height – Acrophobia

Fear of dogs- Cynophobia

Fear of snakes- Ophidiophobia

Fear of water - hydrophobia

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 9.4, specific phobia, page 403

questions.text: Oedipus complex and castration anxiety are associated with which stages of psychosexual development?
questions.solution:
Phallic/oedipal stage is seen between three to five years of age as per freud's psychosexual theory, during which the child increasingly focuses on genitalia and libido is directed towards others. This stage involves castration anxiety and Oedipus complex in males and penis envy and Electra complex in females. The Oedipal complex refers to the intense attachment to the parents of the opposite sex along with a wish to destroy the parents of the same sex. Resolution of the Oedipal complex involves identification with the same sex parent (i.e. the son identifying with the father).

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4, Theories of personality and psychopathology, page 157-158

questions.text: A teenager is worried about joining the 'all-boys band' group in his school. According to Erik Erikson, he is at what phase of psychosocial development stage?
questions.solution:
Identity vs Role confusion- Adolescence. This stage occurs during adolescence between the ages of approximately 12 to 18. Up to this stage, according to Erikson, development mostly depends upon what is done to us. From here on out, development depends primarily upon what we do. Teens need to develop a sense of self and personal identity. During adolescence, children are exploring their independence and developing a sense of self. As they make the transition from childhood to adulthood, teens may begin to feel confused or insecure about themselves and how they fit into society. As they seek to establish a sense of self, teens may experiment with different roles, activities and behaviours. According to Erikson, this is important to the process of forming a strong identity and developing a sense of direction in life.

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Chapter 4, Theories of personality and psychopathology, page 169
